source.6976adfd:
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import warnings

# from IPython.display import HTML, display
source.02c27dd8:
df = pd.read_csv('../input/kaggle-survey-2020/kaggle_survey_2020_responses.csv')

# subset of survey results - data scientist
dsdf = df[df.Q5 == 'Data Scientist']
source.e4825cc0:
# arrange df for Q5
df5 = pd.DataFrame(df['Q5'].value_counts())
df5 = df5[:-1]

# plot
plt.figure(figsize=(9, 6))
ax = sns.barplot(x="Q5", y=df5.index, data=df5)
sns.despine()
plt.title("Respondents' Profile") 
plt.xlabel("No. of Respondents")

warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")
source.a2593531:
# arrange df for Q20
q20 = pd.DataFrame(dsdf['Q20'].value_counts().reindex(['0-49 employees',
                                          '50-249 employees',
                                          '250-999 employees',
                                          '1000-9,999 employees',
                                          '10,000 or more employees']))


# plot
plt.figure(figsize=(9, 6))
ax = sns.barplot(x="Q20", y=q20.index, data=q20)
sns.despine()
plt.title("Size of the Company, by No. of Employees") 
plt.xlabel("No. of Respondents")
plt.ylabel("No. of Employees in Company")

warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

source.f0a44f2a:
# arrange df for q23
q23 = pd.DataFrame(dsdf.loc[:,dsdf.columns.str.startswith("Q23")])
q23e = q23.apply(pd.Series.value_counts)
q23e['Q23_count'] = q23e.loc[:,q23e.columns.str.startswith("Q23")].max(axis=1)
q23e = q23e.sort_values(['Q23_count'], ascending=False)

# plot
plt.figure(figsize=(9, 6))
ax = sns.barplot(x="Q23_count", y=q23e.index, data=q23e)
sns.despine()
plt.title("Activities at work") 
plt.xlabel("No. of Respondents")

warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

source.3ce4da9d: # Part 3: Acquiring the Tools of the Trade
source.2131a509:
🔍 Results

Python leads the way by a significant margin, no doubt due to its more recently exploding popularity and easy-to-understand and clean syntax. SQL has been around for ages since its creation in [1970](http://www.businessnewsdaily.com/5804-what-is-sql.html#:~:text=%2C%22%20Palic%20said.-,SQL%20history,Data%20Banks%2C%22%20in%201970.), and is mainly used to manage data in relationship databases.

📣 What It Means

Python enables the user to experiment with the data, by quickly slicing and dicing data and plotting charts. This easy-to-learn and understand language provides user an all-in-one platform to explore the datasets. Further, there are plenty of resources available for Python online for anyone who's interested to learn. Also, given Python's popularity, there are many open-sourced libraries for developers to expand its functionality. Given that many are now picking up Python, instead of the skillset being an advantage, in the future, it could possibly be seen as a skill as essential as knowing how to access your email inbox. *Reference: Q7 - What programming languages do you use on a regular basis? (Select all that apply)*
source.14098396:
🔍 Results

The largest chunk of work that occupies a data scientist at work is analyzing and understanding data to influence product or business decisions. This is expected and also demonstrates that data science can provide a tangible and measurable benefit to the business operations. As a basis of all data science projects, analyzing and understanding data is critical and wrongly interpreting data could result in unpleasant outcomes.

📣 What It Means

Since companies are in possession of various data of different sorts depending on the industry, one can assume that having specific industry / product knowledge will also help a data scientist in interpreting data and providing solutions / making recommendations. Moving forward, there will be a demand for data scientists with not only data science skills, but also specific industry knowledge. Of course, such a candidate will be hard to find, but a rare and valuable one! 🦄 *Reference: Q23 - Select any activities that make up an important part of your role at work: (Select all that apply)*
source.13d828c5: Part 2.2: How many data scientists among us
source.2ea0f3e6: # Is data science a trend, or is it here to stay?
source.eb625943:
🔍 Results

You will notice that many survey respondents' companies have more than 20+ individuals or 1-2 individuals responsible for data science workloads. With more than 20 employees working on data science workloads, we can safely assume there is an established data science team / function / department. This also tells us that data science value-adds to these companies such that they are willing to spend resources to hire and build a team. Such work environments will provide more job stability and career progression for the data scientist. For companies with 1-2 individuals working on data science, this could suggest perhaps a one-man show or distributed data science duties / capabilities / multi-hatting in addition to other roles employees may be responsible for.

📣 What It Means

There is a wide range in terms of numbers of employees working on data science workloads in the companies. However, this also suggests that perhaps many companies have yet to or are in the process of building up a data science team, thus providing many opportunities to suitable candidates. *Reference: Q21 - Approximately how many individuals are responsible for data science workloads at your place of business?*
source.11ba5db6:
🔍 Results

Overwhelmingly, data scientists surveyed indicated they just need a personal computer or a laptop!

📣 What It Means

This lowers the barrier of entry to the data science trade. A personal computer is not a specialized piece of equipment, it is widely available and second-hand options are also available for purchase at reduced prices too. This opens the doors to willing learners. *Reference: Q11 - What type of computing platform do you use most often for your data science projects?*
source.3f6f9df3:
🔍 Results

Local development environments like RStudio, JupyterLab etc. takes the lead in this question. It is the most popular choice, over traditional analytical software like Excel (which is still widely used in many corporations) and newer competitors like Google Sheets.

📣 What It Means

This perhaps has more to do with costs and functionality. Microsoft Excel requires the purchase of a license to use, and although it is not a huge amount, it is still an investment. On the other hand, open-sourced software like RStudio, Jupyter Notebook etc. is user-friendly and free to download. Further, there are plenty of resources online available to teach users how to make use of these environments. They also offer way more functionality then traditional basic statistical software, and can handle larger datasets. *Reference: Q38 - What is the primary tool that you use at work or school to analyze data? (Include text response)*
source.fdc7ddc4: # Part 1: Kaggle Survey 2020: Exploring the data scientists subset
source.f52c9265:
🔍 Results

From the survey results, it seems that most data scientists make less than USD 999 on an annual basis, which at first glance does not seem to make the endeavor a worthy pursuit. However, we bear in mind that perhaps this reflects on data scientists beginning on this path, those working part-time, pursuing data science as an interest, or even accounting for wage differences in different countries. Encouragingly, the second most common response to the yearly compensation question is $100,000 to 124,999 - which is a pretty decent wage! 💰

📣 What It Means

According to [PayScale](http://www.payscale.com/research/SG/Job=Data_Scientist/Salary/54970bde/Singapore), the average salary of a data scientist in Singapore is around USD 54,000. This is around 31 percent higher than the median wage in Singapore, which is around USD 41,000 in [2020](http://stats.mom.gov.sg/Pages/Income-Summary-Table.aspx) - a reflection of the demand for data science skills. Given the well-publicized shortage of data scientists, we can expect compensation to increase to compensate for the low supply and high demand. *Reference: Q24 - What is your current yearly compensation ( approximate $USD )?*
source.583cde1b:
Much has already been said about the benefits of data-driven decisions. There has been continuous hype surrounding data sciences that being a data scientist was popularly described as the sexiest job of the 21st century by [Harvard Business Review back in 2012](http://hbr.org/2012/10/data-scientist-the-sexiest-job-of-the-21st-century).

But is this a cult movement? Or is this here to stay? How are data scientists doing today? What does their work environment look like? What do they do at work and what tools do they employ? Will data science literacy be as critical as communication skills in the future world?
source.e0b4e100: Part 2.4: Is the reward worthy enough to pursue
source.c394c32b: Part 2.1: What companies are data scientists working in
source.89ba8cc9:
🔍 Results

Kaggle is the top choice for data scientists on keeping up-to-date, followed by blogs, YouTube etc. Most of these media sources are free, available to anyone with an internet connection. This makes learning and keeping up-to-date with data science topics open to anyone who's interested. Contrast this to the past, when information was not freely available, perhaps one had to pay a hefty sum to subscribe to trade newsletters or magazines to find out what's happening!

📣 What It Means

With change being the only constant, we can expect many changes in the field of data science in the future. Keeping up to date with industry news is then important so as not miss out on developments. Technologies has made this easier than before. *Reference: Q39 - Who/what are your favorite media sources that report on data science topics? (Select all that apply)*
source.377b3342:
🔍 Results

The Jupyter suite of products are most popular. It is easy-to-use, and the interactive environment across many languages makes it user-friendly and inviting to use.

📣 What It Means

With its popularity, many online tutorials and articles can be found online that helps a new user ease into the environment. Further, these open-sourced environments are free to use. This also allows anyone who is a willing learner to easily download the Jupyter environment to try their hands out at data science. What's not to like about Jupyter? 🪐 *Reference: Q9 - Which of the following integrated development environments (IDE's) do you use on a regular basis? (Select all that apply)*

source.749ddfa8: # Part 2: Who is the data scientist
source.a25ce4c7:
🔍 Results

From the Kaggle Survey 2020, data scientists represent the second largest group of respondents after students. Over 2600 respondents identified as a data scientist, accounting for around 14% of total respondents. This is a rather substantial representation among survey respondents. *Reference: Q5 - Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired).*
source.2b9ff6a3:
Given the pervasiveness of data in all aspects of life and society, with technologies making the collection of data easier by the day, it is no doubt that data will continue to play a huge part of our lives moving forward.

How do we capitalize on this then? We do so by not falling behind in terms of data science literacy, we embrace data and data science, to not only make sense of the world we are in, but to also better the world. 🌎 

Given the low barriers to learning data science - no special equipments needed, open-sourced tools, the widespread availability of free or cheap resources to learn from, there's really no excuse! Don't be left behind in the race for data supremacy!
source.5474b436:
🔍 Results

[Coursera](http://www.coursera.org/) is a clear winner from the survey results, with a significant lead over the second choice - [Udemy](http://www.udemy.com/). It is telling of the times we live in given the top 2 choices are online learning platforms. Interesting to note, third in place is university courses resulting in a university degree. This could be due to the increasing availability of university courses specializing in data sciences, since demand for data science would naturally lead to a increase in supply in the form of future workers currently studying in university.

📣 What It Means

It is no longer the case that one has to go a traditional school to acquire knowledge. Knowledge is widely available on various platforms now, and on-demand knowledge allows for flexibility both in time and in location. It is also usually cheaper to attend an online course compared to a traditional school. However, given that online learning platforms are still facing issues of legitimacy and market over-saturation, perhaps employers are still keen to hire those with formal qualifications from an established university. Having said that, I am optimistic that online certifications will be even more widely-accepted in the future, perhaps being on par with traditional school certificates. Perhaps, employers will move from assessing candidates based on qualifications to assessing candidates based on the skill sets they possess. *Reference: Q37 - On which platforms have you begun or completed data science courses? (Select all that apply)*
source.fba6a066:
🔍 Results

Most data scientists work in smaller companies with fewer employees (49 and below), and this is followed by working in very large companies (10,000 or more employees). We can speculate various reasons for this result: For the **smaller companies**: * They could be start ups, open to new technologies and aggressively adopting data-based solutions to problems * With lesser levels of hierarchy, it enables the company to make a quick decision to adopt data-based solutions * They see the largest benefit from the skill sets of data scientists, where a small investment in resources could yield results from data they always had but had no idea what to make sense of For the **larger companies**: * They are aware of the benefits of data-driven decisions, and have both the resources and reputation to attract data scientist to join them * Being in short supply, data scientists can take their pick and choose to work in larger companies where compensation, benefits, and progression routes are better This is not to say data scientists only work in very small or very large companies. It is good to note that there is a healthy spread of data scientists working across companies of different sizes. This signals that companies, regardless of sizes or perhaps industry type (perhaps we can include this in next year's Kaggle survey!), are hiring data scientists, embracing data front and center.

📣 What It Means

Clearly, more opportunities for data scientists in the future as data science become a must-have in all companies. *Reference: Q20 - What is the size of the company where you are employed?*
